qas.question: How old will the two Queen Elizabeth ships be?

context: The British Royal Navy is constructing <a0_0><b5_0>two new larger STOVL aircraft carriers, the Queen Elizabeth class<b5_0/><a0_0/>, to replace the three Invincible-class carriers. The ships will be named <a1_0><b6_0>HMS Queen Elizabeth and HMS Prince of Wales<b6_0/><a1_0/>. They will be able to operate up to 40 aircraft in peace time with a tailored group of up to 50, and will have a displacement of <a3_0><b8_0>70,600<b8_0/><a3_0/> tonnes. The ships are due to become operational from <a2_0><b7_0>2020<b7_0/><a2_0/>. Their primary aircraft complement will be made up of F-35B Lightning IIs, and their ship's company will number around 680 with the total complement rising to about 1,600 when the air group is embarked. Defensive weapons will include the Phalanx Close-In Weapons System for anti-aircraft and anti-missile defence; also 30 mm Automated Small Calibre Guns and miniguns for use against fast attack craft. The two ships will be <a4_0><b9_0>the largest warships ever built for the Royal Navy<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
